key_title: Key to the species of Cassinia

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Dicotyledons
Key to the genera of Asteraceae

source.author: Puttock, C.F.
source.title: Cassinia
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae
source.citation: From: Puttock, C.F. (1999). Cassinia. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Capitula arranged ± alternately along inflorescence axes; inflorescence height equal to or longer than width; florets 2 or 3 per capitulum
Capitula arranged in compound dichasia; inflorescence height shorter than wide; florets usually at least 4 per capitulum
Inflorescence red, brown or purplish; corolla lobes red to purple; main branches rarely exceeding 1 cm diam.
Inflorescence white or cream; corolla lobes white; main branches up to 1.5 cm diam.
Cypselas brown, purple or black, usually constricted at apex, with pericarp closely adherent to seed, ridged or more or less cylindrical, glabrous or with elongate twin hairs

Cypselas grey to silvery-white, not or scarcely constricted at apex, irregularly 4- or 5-ridged longitudinally with a loose pericarp, glabrous or with subsessile globular hairs (very rarely sparse twin hairs)

Capitula round in transverse section; involucral bracts membranous (cellophane-like), lamina hyaline throughout or white opaque only at extreme tip, arranged spirally, never longitudinally ranked; capitula all ± sessile in very dense flat-topped heads; pappus often absent

Capitula strongly 5-angled in transverse section; involucral bracts cartilaginous, lamina of at least the inner ones opaque white, arranged in 5 longitudinal ranks when capitulum is mature; capitula shortly pedunculate; inflorescence relatively open; pappus always present
Involucral bracts arranged more or less spirally
Involucral bracts arranged into 5 strong vertical ranks
All involucral bracts smooth, not undulate; leaves grey-green to blue-green, loosely terete to flattened (alpine plants)
At least inner involucral bracts undulate; leaves midgreen to blue-green, linear to oblong (plants of subcoastal swampy areas in south-west)
Plants lacking a sticky resinous coating; involucral bracts in 5 ranks of c. 5
Plants sticky, with a viscid resinous coating on young stems, upper surfaces of leaves and often involucral bracts; involucral bracts in 5 ranks of c. 3 or 4
Capitula 2.5–2.8 mm (rarely to 3.0 mm) long; style c. 1.1 mm long; corolla tube 1.5–1.6(–2.3) mm long
Capitula 3.3–5.0 mm long; style 1.8–2.0 mm long; corolla tube 1.7–2.5 mm long
Capitula 4.5–5.0 mm long, usually lacking resinous coating; corolla tube 2.2–2.5 mm long; inner involucral bracts 3.5–4.0 mm long
Capitula 3.3–4.2(–5.0) mm long, usually covered at least at base with a resinous coating; corolla tube 1.7–2.0 (–2.2) mm long; inner involucral bracts 2.9–3.3 mm long
Leaves glabrous adaxially, with very short acicular gland-tipped hairs on the lamina (but not midrib) abaxially
Leaves pilose adaxially and abaxially

Young stems cottony tomentose, leaves (at least when young) sparsely cottony tomentose adaxially, densely cottony tomentose throughout abaxially, truncate at base; at least the lateral capitula of dichasial groups shortly pedunculate
Young stems with dense acicular gland-tipped hairs; leaves with dense acicular gland-tipped hairs (shorter than on young stems) on both surfaces, shortly auriculate at base; all capitula sessile
Mature cypselas longitudinally ribbed, glabrous or rarely with occassional twin hairs near apex
Mature cypselas smooth, unribbed, usually with moderately dense twin hairs
Leaves to 40 mm long, if ever to 50 mm, then adaxial surfaces aculeate to shortly hispid; margins strongly recurved to revolute; foliage not viscid
At least the longest leaves mostly 40 mm long or more, adaxial surface smooth; margins not or barely recurved; new growth typically rather viscid
Inflorescences ochre-coloured, usually with 20–50 (rarely up to 200) capitula; northwest
Inflorescences dull white (occasionally pink fading to white); absent from northwest
Leaves with only the midrib prominent
Leaves with 3 prominent veins
